1-8-4: Not Additional Remedy
1-8-1: REQUEST FOR HEARING:
Unless otherwise specifically provided in any ordinance of the city or any code
adopted by reference, a hearing before the city council may be requested by any
person:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Who is denied or refused a permit or license by any officer, agent or
employee of this city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Whose permit or license is revoked, restricted, qualified or limited
from that for which it was first issued. (1977 Code Â§ 1-411)
1-8-2: FORM OF REQUEST:
The request for hearing must be made in writing to the mayor or city recorder
and made within thirty (30) days following the date notice denying, refusing,
revoking, qualifying or restricting the license or permit is mailed by the city
to the applicant or license holder at his address as it appears on the
application or license. (1977 Code Â§ 1-412)
1-8-3: PROCEDURE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Time And Place: Following receipt of a request for hearing, the city
council shall inform the person requesting a hearing of the time and place the
hearing is to be held.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Witnesses; Evidence: At the hearing, the aggrieved party shall have the
right to hear and examine any witnesses the city may produce to support its
decision and to present his own evidence in support of his contention.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Decision Of City Council: The city council shall, within ten (10) days
following the conclusion of the hearing, in writing, inform the person who
requested the hearing of the decision of the city council. (1977 Code Â§ 1-413)
1-8-4: NOT ADDITIONAL REMEDY:
This chapter shall not be construed so as to afford any aggrieved party more
than one hearing before the city council, nor shall the hearing provided in
this section apply to any criminal complaint or proceeding. (1977 Code Â§ 1-414)

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Elected Officials: Any elected official of the municipality shall at
all times have the right to inspect the books, records and papers of the city.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Toquerville City will adhere to the Utah State General Records
Retention Schedule. It can be found on the Utah Division of Archives and
Records Services website. (1977 Code Â§ 3-344; amd. 2014 Code; Ord. 2023.18, 8-
2-2023)
CHAPTER 10
ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT PROGRAM
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-10A-1: Short Title
1-10A-2: Declaration Of Purpose

1-10A-4: Existing Law Continued
1-10A-5: Criminal Prosecution Right
1-10A-6: Effect Of Heading
1-10A-7: Validity Of Chapter And Severability
1-10A-8: No Mandatory Duty Or Civil Liability
1-10A-9: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-10A-10: Definitions
1-10A-11: Acts Include Causing, Aiding And Abetting
1-10A-12: Service Of Process
1-10A-13: Constructive Notice Of Recorded Documents
1-10A-14: General Enforcement Authority
1-10A-15: Adoption Of Policy And Procedures
1-10A-16: Authority To Inspect
1-10A-17: False Information Or Refusal Prohibited
1-10A-18: Failure To Obey Subpoena
1-10A-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT HEARING
PROGRAMÂ (ACE HEARING PROGRAM). (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-2: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
The city council finds that the enforcement of this code and applicable state
codes throughout the city is an important public service. Code enforcement is
vital to the protection of the public health, safety and quality of life. The
city council recognizes that enforcement starts with the drafting of precise
regulations that can be effectively applied in administrative code enforcement
hearings and judicial proceedings. The city council further finds that a
comprehensive code enforcement system that uses a combination of judicial and
administrative remedies is critical to gain compliance with these regulations.
Failure to comply with an administrative code enforcement action may require
the city attorney to file a judicial action to gain compliance. (Ord. 2014.04,
9-11-2014)
1-10A-3: SCOPE:
The provisions of this chapter may be applied to all violations of this code.
It has been designed as an additional remedy for the city to use in achieving
compliance of its ordinances. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-4: EXISTING LAW CONTINUED:
The provisions of this chapter do not invalidate any other chapter or ordinance
of this code, but shall be read in conjunction with those chapters and
ordinances as an additional remedy available for enforcement of those
ordinances. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-5: CRIMINAL PROSECUTION RIGHT:
The city has sole discretion in deciding whether to file a civil or criminal
case for the violation of any of its ordinances. The city may choose to file
both, or one or the other. The enactment of this administrative remedy shall in
no way interfere with the city's right to prosecute city ordinance violations
as criminal offenses. The city may use any of the remedies available under the
law in both civil and criminal prosecution. If the city chooses to file both
civil and criminal charges for the same day of violation, no civil penalties
may be assessed, but all other remedies are available. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-
2014)
1-10A-6: EFFECT OF HEADING:
Title, chapter, article, part and section headings contained in this chapter
shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify, or in any manner affect the
scope, meaning, or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter, article,
part, or section hereof. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-7: VALIDITY OF CHAPTER AND SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, portion, or provision of
this chapter is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by the
decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. The city council hereby
declares that it would have adopted this chapter and each section, subsection,
sentence, clause, phrase, portion, or provision thereof, irrespective of the
fact that one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses, phrases,
portions or provisions be declared invalid or unconstitutional. This section
shall apply to all amendments heretofore or hereafter made to this chapter.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-8: NO MANDATORY DUTY OR CIVIL LIABILITY:
It is the intent of the city council that in establishing performance standards
or establishing an obligation to act by a city officer or employee, these
standards shall not be construed as creating a mandatory duty for purposes of
tort liability if the officer or employee fails to perform his or her directed
duty or duties. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-9: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
For purposes of this chapter:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any gender includes the other gender.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Words used in the present tense include the past and future tense, and
vice versa.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Words and phrases used in this chapter and not specifically defined
shall be construed according to the context and approved usage of the language.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-10: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, whenever used in this chapter, shall be
construed as defined in this section, unless a different meaning is
specifically stated to apply:
ABATEMENT: Any action the city may take on public or private property and any
adjacent property as may be necessary to remove or alleviate a violation,
including, but not limited to, demolition, removal, repair, boarding and
securing or replacement of property.
ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT HEARING PROGRAM ADMINISTRATOR OR ACE
ADMINISTRATOR: Any person authorized by the mayor and city council to
supervise, administer the administrative code enforcement hearing program, and
enforce violations of this code or applicable sections of the Utah code.
ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT ORDER: An order issued by an administrative law
judge. The order may include an order to abate the violation, pay civil
penalties and administrative costs, or take any other action as authorized or
required by this chapter, this code and applicable sections of the Utah code.
ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE (ALJ): The administrative law judge appointed by the
mayor and city council to preside over the administrative code enforcement
hearings established herein.
CITY: Toquerville City, a Utah municipal corporation, and the area within the
territorial city limits of the city, and such territory outside of the city
over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional
or incorporation provisions or any law.
CITY CODE: The Toquerville City code.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city.
CITY FEE SCHEDULE: The fee schedule adopted by the city council that sets forth
civil penalties, administrative fees, abatement costs and the applicable
interest rate for enforcement of this chapter. The city fee schedule is on file
in the office of the city recorder.
CODE ENFORCEMENT PERFORMANCE BOND: A bond posted by a responsible person to
ensure compliance with this code, applicable sections of the Utah code, a
judicial action, or an administrative code enforcement order.
CODE ENFORCEMENT TAX LIEN: A lien recorded to collect outstanding civil
penalties, administrative fees and abatement costs.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL: Any person authorized to enforce violations of this code,
this chapter or applicable sections of the Utah code.
FINANCIAL INSTITUTION: Any person that holds a recorded mortgage or deed of
trust on a property.
GOOD CAUSE: Incapacitating illness; death; lack of proper notice;
unavailability due to unavoidable, unpreventable or extenuating emergency or
circumstance; if a required act causes an imminent and irreparable injury; and
acts of nature adverse to performing required acts.
IMMINENT LIFE SAFETY HAZARD: Any condition that creates a present, extreme, and
immediate danger to life, property, health or public safety.
LEGAL INTEREST: Any interest that is represented by a document, such as a deed
of trust, quitclaim deed, mortgage, judgment lien, tax or assessment lien,
mechanics' lien, or other similar instrument that is recorded in the official
records on file in the office of the recorder of Washington County, state of
Utah.
NOTICE OF COMPLIANCE: A document issued by the city, representing that a
property complies with the requirements outlined in the notice of violation.
NOTICE OF SATISFACTION: A document or form approved by the administrative law
judge or his or her designee, which indicates that all outstanding civil
penalties and costs have been either paid in full, or that the city has
negotiated an agreed amount, or that a subsequent administrative or judicial
decision has resolved the outstanding debt. In addition to the satisfaction of
the financial debt, the property must also be in compliance with the
requirements outlined in the notice of violation.
NOTICE OF VIOLATION: A written notice prepared by an enforcement official that
informs a responsible person of this code or Utah code violations and orders
the responsible person to take certain steps to correct the violations.
OATH: Includes affirmations and oaths.
PERSON: Any natural person, firm, joint venture, joint stock company,
partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business trust,
organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, sergeant, officer, or employee of
any of them, or any other entity that is recognized by law as the subject of
rights or duties.
PROPERTY OWNER: The record owner of real property based on the official records
on file in the office of the assessor of Washington County, state of Utah.
PUBLIC NUISANCE: Any condition caused, maintained or permitted to exist that
constitutes a threat to the public's health, safety and welfare, or that
significantly obstructs, injures or interferes with the reasonable or free use
of property in a neighborhood or community or by any considerable number of
persons. A public nuisance also has the same meaning as set forth in the Utah
code and this code.
RESPONSIBLE PERSON: A person who is responsible for causing or maintaining a
violation of this code or applicable sections of the Utah code. The property
owner, tenant, person with a legal interest in the real property, or person in
possession of the real property shall be liable for any violation maintained on
the property. In all cases, the property owner shall be considered a
responsible person.
WRITTEN: Includes handwritten, typewritten, photocopied, computer printed or
facsimile. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-11: ACTS INCLUDE CAUSING, AIDING AND ABETTING:
Whenever any act or omission is made unlawful in this chapter, it shall include
causing, permitting, aiding or abetting such act or omission. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-
11-2014)
1-10A-12: SERVICE OF PROCESS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Methods: Whenever service is required to be given under this chapter
for enforcement purposes, the document shall be served by any of the following
methods, unless different provisions are otherwise specifically stated to
apply:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Regular mail, postage prepaid, to the last known address of the
owner or other responsible person;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Posting the notice conspicuously on or in front of the property. If
not inhabited, the notice must also be mailed as in subsection A1 of this
section. The form of the posted notice shall be approved by the ACE
administrator or his or her designee;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Personal service pursuant to Utah rules of civil procedure, rule 4
(e)(1) or rule 4(e)(5); or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Published in a newspaper of general circulation where the identity
or whereabouts of the person to be served are unknown and cannot be ascertained
through reasonable diligence, where service is impracticable under the
circumstances, or where there exists good cause to believe that the person to
be served is avoiding service of process.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â When Deemed Served: Service by regular mail in the manner described
above shall be deemed served on the fifth day after the date of mailing.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Deemed Valid Service: If service complies with the requirements of this
section, it shall be deemed a valid service even if a party claims not to have
received the service and it shall not affect the validity of any proceedings
taken under this chapter.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Validity Of Failure To Serve All Persons: The failure to serve all
responsible persons shall not affect the validity of any proceedings. (Ord.
2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-13: CONSTRUCTIVE NOTICE OF RECORDED DOCUMENTS:
Whenever a document is recorded in the official records in file in the office
of the recorder of Washington County, state of Utah, as authorized or required
by this chapter or applicable sections of the Utah code, recordation shall
provide constructive notice of the information contained in the recorded
documents. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-14: GENERAL ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY:
Whenever the ACE administrator or any enforcement official finds that a
violation of this code or applicable sections of the Utah code has occurred or
continues to exist, the appropriate administrative enforcement procedure may be
used as outlined in this chapter. The ACE administrator or enforcement official
has the authority and power necessary to gain compliance with the provisions of
this code and applicable state codes. These powers include the power to issue
notices of violation and administrative citations, inspect public and private
property, abate public and private property, and use whatever judicial and
administrative remedies are available under this code or applicable sections of
the Utah code. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-15: ADOPTION OF POLICY AND PROCEDURES:
The ALJ is authorized to develop policies and procedures relating to the
hearing procedures, scope of hearings, subpoena powers and other matters
relating to the administrative code enforcement hearings program. (Ord.
2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-16: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT:
The ACE administrator or any enforcement official is authorized to enter upon
any property or premises to ascertain whether the provisions of this code or
applicable sections of the Utah code are being obeyed and to make any
examinations and surveys as may be necessary in the performance of the
enforcement duties. This may include the taking of photographs, samples or
other physical evidence. All inspections, entries, examinations and surveys
shall be done in a reasonable manner based upon cause. If the responsible
person refuses to allow the ACE administrator or enforcement official to enter
the property, the ACE administrator or enforcement official shall obtain a
search warrant. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10A-17: FALSE INFORMATION OR REFUSAL PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully make a false statement or
refuse to give his or her name or address with intent to deceive or interfere
with the ACE administrator or an enforcement official when in the performance
of his or her official duties under the provisions of this chapter. A violation
of this section is a class B misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014; amd. 2014 Code)
1-10A-18: FAILURE TO OBEY SUBPOENA:
It is unlawful for any person to refuse or fail to obey a subpoena issued for
an administrative code enforcement hearing. Failure to obey a subpoena
constitutes contempt and may be prosecuted as a class B misdemeanor, subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014; amd. 2014 Code)
ARTICLE B. ABATEMENT AND NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS
SECTION:

1-10B-1: AUTHORITY:
Any condition caused, maintained or permitted to exist in violation of any
provisions of this code or applicable state codes that constitutes a violation
may be abated by the city pursuant to the procedures set forth in this article.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10B-2: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Information Included: Whenever the ACE administrator or any enforcement
official determines that a violation of this code or applicable section of the
Utah code has occurred or continues to exist, the ACE administrator or
enforcement official may choose to proceed under the ACE program. If this
procedure is used, a notice of violation shall be issued to a responsible
person. The notice of violation shall include the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Name of property owner or responsible person;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Street address of violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Date violation observed;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All city code and applicable Utah code sections violated and
description of condition of the property that violates the applicable codes;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A statement explaining the type of remedial action required to
permanently correct outstanding violations, which may include corrections,
repairs, demolition, removal or other appropriate action;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Specific date to correct the violations listed in the notice of the
violation, which date shall be at least the number of days set forth in the
city fee schedule from the date of service;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Explanation of the consequences should the responsible person fail
to comply with the terms and deadlines as prescribed in the notice of
violation, which may include, but is not limited to, criminal prosecution;
civil penalties; revocation of permits; recordation of the notice of violation;
withholding of future municipal permits; abatement of the violation; costs of
abatement; lien on property; administrative fees; and any other legal remedies;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â That civil penalties will begin to accrue immediately on expiration
of the date to correct violations;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The amount of the civil penalty on each violation and that the
penalty will accrue daily until the violation is brought into compliance;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â That only one notice of violation is required for any twelve (12)
month period, and that civil penalties begin immediately upon any subsequent
violations of the notice. The responsible person may request a hearing on the
renewed violations by following the same procedure as provided for the original
notice;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Procedures to request a hearing as provided in section
1-10D-3 of this chapter, and consequences for failure to request one.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Service Of Notice: The notice of violation shall be served by one of
the methods of service listed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Multiple Notices: More than one notice of violation may be issued
against the same responsible person, if it encompasses different dates or
different violations. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10B-3: FAILURE TO BRING PROPERTY INTO COMPLIANCE:
If a responsible person fails to bring a violation into compliance within the
time set forth on the notice of violation after service of the notice of
violation, civil penalties shall be owed to the city for each and every
subsequent day of violation. Failure to comply with the notice of violation is
a class B misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014; amd. 2014 Code)
1-10B-4: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the responsible person served with a notice of
violation to request an inspection when his or her property has been brought
into compliance. It is prima facie evidence that the violation remains on the
property if no inspection is requested. Civil penalties accumulate daily until
the property has been inspected and a notice of compliance is issued.
Reinspection fees shall be assessed pursuant to the "remedies" section of this
chapter, if more than one inspection is necessary. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10B-5: EMERGENCY ABATEMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Authorized: Whenever the ACE administrator determines that an imminent
life safety hazard exists that requires immediate correction or elimination,
the ACE administrator may take immediate action to abate the hazard.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Entrance Upon Property: The ACE administrator or authorized
representative has the authority, based on cause, to enter the property without
a search warrant or court order to abate the safety hazard.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Minimum Level Of Correction: The ACE administrator shall pursue only
the minimum level of correction or abatement as necessary to eliminate the
immediacy of the hazard.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Liability For Costs: The responsible person shall be liable for all
costs associated with the abatement of the imminent life safety hazard. Costs
incurred by the city during the emergency abatement process shall be assessed
and recovered against the responsible person through the procedures outlined in
the "remedies" section of this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Other Remedies: The ACE administrator may also pursue any other
administrative or judicial remedy to abate any remaining violations.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Notice Of Action Taken: After an emergency abatement, the city shall
notify the property owner or responsible person of the abatement action taken.
This notice shall be served within ten (10) days of completion of the
abatement. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
ARTICLE C. ADMINISTRATIVE CITATIONS
SECTION:
1-10C-1: Declaration Of Purpose
1-10C-2: Authority
1-10C-3: Procedures
1-10C-4: Contents Of Administrative Citation
1-10C-5: Civil Penalties Assessed
1-10C-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
The city council finds that there is a need for an alternative method of
enforcement for minor violations of this code and applicable sections of the
Utah code. The city council further finds that an appropriate method of
enforcement is an administrative citation program. The procedures established
in this article shall be in addition to criminal, civil or any other legal
remedy established by law that may be pursued to address violations of this
code or applicable sections of the Utah code. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10C-2: AUTHORITY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Minor Violations: Any person violating this code or applicable sections
of the Utah code, where said violation is deemed minor by the ACE
administrator, may be issued an administrative citation by an enforcement
official or ACE administrator as provided in this article.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Civil Penalty: A civil penalty shall be assessed by means of an
administrative citation issued by the enforcement official, and shall be
payable directly to the city treasurer's office.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Collection: Penalties assessed by means of an administrative citation
shall be collected in accordance with the procedures specified in the
"remedies" section of this chapter. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10C-3: PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Issuance Of Administrative Citation: Upon discovering any violation of
this code or applicable sections of the Utah code, an enforcement official or
ACE administrator may issue an administrative citation to a responsible person
in the manner prescribed in this article or as prescribed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter. The administrative citation shall be issued on a form
approved by the ALJ.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Location Of Business Owner: If the responsible person is a business,
the enforcement official or ACE administrator shall attempt to locate the
business owner and issue an administrative citation to the business owner. If
the enforcement official or ACE administrator can only locate the manager of
the business, the administrative citation may be given to the manager of the
business. A copy of the administrative citation may also be mailed to the
business owner or any other responsible person in the manner prescribed in
section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Signature Of Responsible Person: Once the responsible person has been
located, the enforcement official or ACE administrator shall attempt to obtain
the signature of that person on the administrative citation. If the responsible
person refuses or fails to sign the administrative citation, the failure or
refusal to sign shall not affect the validity of the citation and subsequent
proceedings.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Unable To Locate Responsible Person: If the enforcement official or ACE
administrator is unable to locate the responsible person for the violation,
then the administrative citation shall be mailed to the responsible person in
the manner prescribed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Posting Of Administrative Citation: If no one can be located at the
property, then the administrative citation may be posted in a conspicuous place
on or near the property and a copy subsequently mailed to the responsible
person in the manner prescribed by section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Signature Of Enforcement Official: The enforcement official or ACE
administrator shall sign the administrative citation.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Failure To Receive Notice: The failure of any person with an interest
in the property to receive notice shall not affect the validity of any
proceedings taken under this article. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10C-4: CONTENTS OF ADMINISTRATIVE CITATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Violation Information: The administrative citation shall refer to the
date and location of the violations and the approximate time the violations
were observed.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Sections Violated: The administrative citation shall refer to this code
or Utah code sections violated and the titles of those sections.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Penalty Amount: The administrative citation shall state the amount of
penalty imposed for the violations.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Explanation Of Penalty: The administrative citation shall explain how
the penalty shall be paid, the time period by which the penalty shall be paid,
and the consequences of failure to pay the penalty.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Request For Hearing: The administrative citation shall identify the
right and the procedures to request a hearing.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Signatures: The administrative citation shall contain the signature of
the enforcement official or ACE administrator and the signature of the
responsible person, unless the responsible person refuses to sign it or
otherwise cannot be located. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10C-5: CIVIL PENALTIES ASSESSED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The ALJ shall establish policies to assist in the assessment of civil
penalties or administrative citations.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Civil penalties shall be assessed immediately for each violation listed
on the administrative citation. The penalties shall be those established in the
city uniform fee schedule.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Payment of the penalty shall not excuse the failure to correct the
violations, nor shall it bar further enforcement action by the city. (Ord.
2014.04, 9-11-2014)
ARTICLE D. HEARING PROCEDURES; POWERS OF ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE;
ADMINISTRATIVE ENFORCEMENT ORDERS; APPEALS
SECTION:
1-10D-1: Declaration Of Purpose

1-10D-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
The city council finds that there is a need to establish uniform procedures for
administrative code enforcement hearings (ACE hearings) conducted pursuant to
this chapter. It is the purpose and intent of the city council to afford due
process of law to any person who is directly affected by an administrative
action. Due process of law includes notice, an opportunity to participate in an
ACE hearing, and an explanation of the reasons justifying the administrative
action. These procedures are also intended to establish a forum to efficiently,
expeditiously and fairly resolve issues raised in any administrative code
enforcement action. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-2: AUTHORITY AND SCOPE OF ACE HEARINGS:
Enforcement of this code and applicable sections of the Utah code violations
may be conducted through the administrative code enforcement procedures
established by this chapter, presided over by the administrative law judge
(ALJ). The ALJ shall develop policies and procedures to regulate the hearing
process for any violation of this code and applicable sections of the Utah code
that are handled pursuant to the administrative abatement procedures, the
emergency abatement procedures, the demolition procedures or the administrative
citation procedures. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-3: REQUEST FOR ACE HEARING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Right To Request: A person served with one of the following documents
or notices has the right to request an administrative code enforcement hearing,
if the request is filed within ten (10) calendar days from the date of service
of one of the following notices:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Notice of violation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Notice of itemized statement of costs or fees;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Administrative citation; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Notice of emergency abatement.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Filing Request: The request for hearing shall be made in writing and
filed with the ACE administrator. The request shall contain the case/citation
or notice number, the address of the violation, and the signature of the
responsible party (ACE hearing request). The ACE administrator shall forward
the ACE hearing request to the ALJ within five (5) business days.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Hearing Scheduled: As soon as practicable after receiving the ACE
hearing request, the ALJ shall schedule a date, time and place for the ACE
hearing.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Failure To Request: Failure to request a hearing as provided shall
constitute a waiver of the right to an ACE hearing and a waiver of the right to
challenge the action. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-4: DEFAULT HEARINGS AND ORDERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Default Hearing Set: If the responsible person fails to request an ACE
hearing before the expiration of the ten (10) day deadline, the case shall be
set for a default hearing. The ALJ and the ACE administrator shall schedule a
default hearing (default hearing). The responsible person shall be notified of
the date, time and place of the default hearing by one of the methods listed in
section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Scheduling: A default hearing shall be scheduled for all cases that
have outstanding or unpaid civil penalties, administrative fees and/or
abatement costs due to the city before collection, if a hearing on that case
has not already been held.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Evidence Presented: At the default hearing, the responsible person
shall have the opportunity to present evidence to show that "good cause"
exists, as defined in section
1-10A-10 of this chapter, to do one or more of the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Waive or reduce the fines which have accumulated;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Postpone an abatement action by the city; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Excuse the responsible person's failure to request a hearing within
the ten (10) day period.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Order Of ALJ: If the responsible person fails to establish good cause
to take one or more of the actions set forth in the preceding subsection, the
ALJ shall review the notice of violation or administrative citation and any
other relevant information included in the case file. The ALJ shall not accept
any other evidence. If the evidence shows that the violations existed, the ALJ
shall enter an order requiring abatement of the violations, and the payment of
all penalties, fees and costs. Penalties shall run until the city issues a
notice of compliance stating when the violations were actually abated. (Ord.
2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-5: NOTIFICATION OF HEARINGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Written Notice: Written notice of the day, time and place of the ACE
hearing or default hearing shall be served to a responsible person as soon as
practicable prior to the date of the said hearing.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Format, Contents: The format and contents of the hearing notice shall
be in accordance with rules and policies promulgated by the administrative law
judge.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Service Of Notice: The notice of the ACE hearing or the default hearing
shall be served by any of the methods of service listed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-6: DISQUALIFICATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE:
The administrative law judge is subject to disqualification for bias,
prejudice, interest or any other reason for which a judge may be disqualified
in a court of law. Rules and procedures for disqualification and replacement
shall be promulgated by the ALJ. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-7: POWERS OF ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â General Authority: The ALJ has the authority to hold hearings,
determine if violations of this code or applicable sections of the Utah code
exists, order compliance with this code or applicable sections of the Utah
code, and enforce compliance as provided in this chapter on any matter subject
to the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Continuance Of Hearing: The ALJ may continue a hearing (ACE hearing or
default hearing) based on good cause shown by one of the parties to the
hearing. The ALJ must enter on the record the good cause on which a continuance
is granted.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Issue Subpoenas: The ALJ, at the request of any party to a hearing, may
sign subpoenas for witnesses, documents and other evidence where the attendance
of the witness for the admission of evidence is deemed necessary to decide the
issues at the hearing. All costs related to the subpoena, including witness and
mileage fees, shall be borne by the party requesting the subpoena. Said costs
may be recovered by the city from the responsible party where the ALJ finds
that a violation existed. The ALJ shall develop policies and procedures
relating to the issuance of subpoenas in ACE hearings, including the form of
the subpoena and related costs.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Jurisdiction: The ALJ has continuing jurisdiction over the subject
matter of an ACE hearing or default hearing for the purposes of granting a
continuance; ordering compliance by issuing an administrative code enforcement
order using any remedies available under the law; ensuring compliance of that
order, which includes the right to authorize the city to enter and abate a
violation; modifying an administrative code enforcement order; or, where
extraordinary circumstances exist, granting a new hearing.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Requirement To Post Bond: The ALJ has the authority to require a
responsible person to post a code enforcement performance bond to ensure
compliance with an administrative code enforcement order. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-
2014)
1-10D-8: PROCEDURES AT HEARING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Informal: ACE hearings are intended to be informal in nature. Formal
rules of evidence and discovery do not apply; however, an informal exchange of
discovery may be required. The request must be in writing. Failure to request
discovery shall not be a basis for a continuance. Complainant information is
protected and shall not be released unless the complainant is a witness at the
hearing. The procedure and format of the administrative hearing shall follow
the procedures promulgated by the ALJ.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Burden Of Proof: The city bears the burden of proof at an ACE hearing
to establish the existence of a violation of this code or applicable sections
of the Utah code.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Standard Of Proof: The standard of proof to be used by the ALJ in
deciding the issues at an ACE hearing is whether the preponderance of the
evidence shows that the violation exists.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Testimony: Each party shall have the opportunity to cross examine
witnesses and present evidence in support of his or her case. A written
declaration signed under penalty of perjury may be accepted in lieu of a
personal appearance if the written declaration is provided to the opposing at
least seven (7) days before the hearing. Testimony may be given by telephone or
other electronic means.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Open Hearings: All ACE hearings and default hearings are open to the
public. They shall be recorded by audiotape. Hearings may be held at the
location of the violation.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Attorney Representation: The responsible person has a right to be
represented by an attorney. If an attorney will be representing the responsible
person at the hearing, notice of the attorney's name, address and telephone
number must be given to the city at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing.
If notice is not given, the hearing may be continued at the city's request, and
all costs of the continuance assessed to the responsible person.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â New Hearing Requires Extraordinary Circumstances: No new hearing shall
be granted, unless the administrative law judge determines that extraordinary
circumstances exist which justify a new hearing. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-9: FAILURE TO ATTEND HEARING:
Any party whose property or actions are the subject of any ACE hearing or
default hearing and this chapter, and who fails to appear at the hearing is
deemed to waive the right to a hearing and will result in a default judgment
for the city; provided, that proper notice of the hearing has been provided.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-10: ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT ORDER:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Stipulated Agreement: The city and the responsible party may enter into
a stipulated agreement, which must be signed by both parties. This agreement
shall be entered as the administrative code enforcement order. Entry of this
agreement shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing and the right to
appeal.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Administrative Order: Once all evidence and testimony are completed,
the ALJ judge shall issue an administrative code enforcement order that
affirms, modifies, or rejects the notice of violation or administrative
citation. The ALJ may increase or decrease the total amount of civil penalties
and costs that are due pursuant to the city fee schedule and the procedures in
this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Abatement By City: The ALJ may order the city to enter the property and
abate all violations, which may include removing animals kept in violation of
this code.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Kennels, Animal Licensing And Possession: The ALJ may revoke a kennel
permit, an animal license or the right to possess animals as provided in this
code.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Conditions: As part of the administrative code enforcement order, the
ALJ may condition the parties assessment of civil penalties on the responsible
person's ability to complete compliance by specified deadlines.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Subsequent Review Hearings: The ALJ may schedule subsequent review
hearings as may be necessary or as requested by a party to the hearing to
ensure compliance with the administrative code enforcement order.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Posting Of Bond: The ALJ may order the responsible person to post an
administrative code enforcement performance bond to ensure compliance with the
administrative code enforcement order.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Date Order Final: The administrative code enforcement order shall
become final on the date of the signing of the order.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Service Of Order: The administrative code enforcement order shall be
served on all parties by any one of the methods listed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-11: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH ENFORCEMENT ORDER:
Upon the failure of the responsible person to comply with the terms and
deadlines set forth in the administrative code enforcement order, the city may
use all appropriate legal means to recover the civil penalties and
administrative costs to obtain compliance. After the ALJ issues an
administrative code enforcement order, the ACE administrator shall monitor the
violations and determine compliance. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10D-12: APPEAL OF ADMINISTRATIVE CODE ENFORCEMENT ORDER:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Petition For Judicial Review: Any person adversely affected by any
decision made in the exercise of the provisions of this chapter may file a
petition for review of the decision or order by the district court in and for
Washington County, state of Utah, within thirty (30) days after the decision is
rendered (petition for judicial review).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Administrative Remedies Exhausted: No person may challenge in district
court an ALJ's decision until that person has exhausted his or her
administrative remedies.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Request For Copy Of Records: Within one hundred twenty (120) days after
submitting a petition for judicial review, the party petitioning for appeal
shall request a copy of the record of the proceedings, including transcripts of
the ACE hearings and/or default hearings when necessary. The ALJ shall not
submit copies of files or transcripts to the reviewing court until the party
petitioning for appeal has paid all required costs. The petitioning party's
failure to properly arrange for copies of the record, or to pay the full costs
for the record, within one hundred twenty (120) days after the petition for
review was filed shall be grounds for dismissal of the petition for judicial
review.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Remand For Supplemental Procedures: If a transcript of a hearing cannot
be prepared because the tape recording is incomplete or unintelligible, the
district court may, in its discretion, remand the matter to the ALJ for a
supplemental proceeding to complete the record. The district court may limit
the scope of the supplemental proceeding to issues that, in the court's
opinion, need to be clarified.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Review Limited: The district court's review is limited to the record of
the administrative code enforcement order that is being appealed. The district
court shall not accept nor consider any evidence that is not part of the record
of the administrative code enforcement order.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Authority Of Court: The district court shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Presume that the ALJ's decision and orders are valid; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Review the record to determine whether or not the decision was
arbitrary, capricious or illegal. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
ARTICLE E. REMEDIES
SECTION:
1-10E-1: Declaration Of Purpose
1-10E-2: Recordation Of Notice Of Violation; Notice Of Satisfaction
1-10E-3: Prohibition Against Issuance Of Municipal Permits

1-10E-6: Injunctions
1-10E-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
The city council finds that there is a need for alternative methods of
enforcement for violations of this code and applicable sections of the Utah
code that are found to exist. The city council further finds that an
appropriate method of enforcement for these types of violations is the issuance
and recordation of notices of violation. The remedies established in this
article shall be in addition to criminal, civil or any other remedy established
by law that may be pursued to address the violation of this code or applicable
state codes. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10E-2: RECORDATION OF NOTICE OF VIOLATION; NOTICE OF SATISFACTION:
Whenever the ACE administrator determines that a property or violation has not
been brought into compliance as required in this chapter, the ACE administrator
has the authority to record the notice of violation or administrative code
enforcement order with the Washington County recorder's office.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Procedure For Recordation: Recordation of a notice of violation shall
occur according to the following procedures:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Once the ACE administrator or any enforcement official has issued a
notice of violation to a responsible person, and the property remains in
violation after the deadline established in the notice of violation, and no
request for an ACE hearing has been filed, the ACE administrator shall record a
notice of violation in the official records on file in the office of the
recorder of Washington County, state of Utah.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If an ACE hearing is held, and an administrative code enforcement
order is issued in the city's favor, the ACE administrator shall record the
administrative code enforcement order in the official records on file in the
office of the recorder of Washington County, state of Utah.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The recordation shall include the name of the property owner, the
parcel number, the legal description of the parcel, and a copy of the notice of
violation or administrative code enforcement order.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The recordation does not encumber the property, but merely places
future interested parties on notice of any continuing violation found upon the
property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Service Of Notice Of Recordation: A notice of the recordation shall be
served on the responsible person and the property owner pursuant to any of the
methods of service set forth in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Waiver Of Hearing: The failure of any person to file a request for an
ACE hearing when served with a notice of violation shall constitute a waiver of
the right to an ACE hearing and shall not affect the validity of the recorded
notice of violation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Inspection; Satisfaction: When the notice of violations and/or
administrative code enforcement orders have been corrected, the responsible
person or property owner may request an inspection of the property from the ACE
administrator and the issuance of a notice of compliance or notice of
satisfaction, as the case may be.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Upon receipt of a request for inspection, the ACE administrator or
an enforcement official shall reinspect the property as soon as practicable to
determine whether the violations listed in the notice of violation or the
administrative code enforcement order have been corrected, and whether all
necessary permits have been issued and final inspections have been performed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The ACE administrator shall serve a notice of satisfaction or notice
of compliance, as the case may be, to the responsible person or property owner
in the manner provided in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter, if the ACE administrator determines that:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â All violations listed in the recorded notice of violation or
administrative code enforcement order have been corrected;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â All necessary permits have been issued and finalized;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â All civil penalties assessed against the property have been paid
or satisfied; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The party requesting the notice of compliance or notice of
satisfaction, as the case may be, has paid all administrative fees and costs.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â If the ACE administrator denies a request to issue a notice of
compliance or notice of satisfaction, upon request the ACE administrator shall
serve the responsible person with a written explanation setting forth the
reasons for the denial. The written explanation shall be served by any of the
methods of service listed in section
1-10A-12 of this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Recordation of the notice of compliance and notice of satisfaction
shall have the effect of canceling the recorded notice of violation or
administrative code enforcement order. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10E-3: PROHIBITION AGAINST ISSUANCE OF MUNICIPAL PERMITS:
The city may withhold business licenses; permits for kennels; or permits for
any alteration, repair, or construction pertaining to any existing or new
structures or signs on the property; or any permits pertaining to the use and
development of the real property or the structure when the ACE administrator or
any enforcement official has served a notice of violation upon the responsible
party. The city may withhold permits until a notice of compliance or a notice
of satisfaction has been issued by the ACE administrator. The city may not
withhold permits that are necessary to obtain a notice of satisfaction or that
are necessary to correct serious health and safety violations. (Ord. 2014.04,
9-11-2014)
1-10E-4: ADMINISTRATIVE CIVIL PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Applicability: Any person violating any provision of this code or
applicable sections of the Utah code may be subject to the assessment of civil
penalties for each violation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Civil Penalties: Each and every day a violation of any provision of
this code or applicable sections of the Utah code exists is a separate
violation subject to the assessment of civil penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If a responsible person fails to bring a violation into compliance
within the number of days prescribed in the notice of violation after service
of the notice of violation, civil penalties shall be owed to the city for each
and every subsequent day of violation. Civil penalties are assessed and owing
immediately for any violation of this code or the applicable sections of the
Utah code for an administrative citation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Civil penalties shall be assessed per violation per day pursuant to
the city uniform fee schedule for a notice of violation or administrative
citation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Civil penalties shall continue to accrue until the violation(s) has/
have been brought into compliance with this code or applicable sections of the
Utah code and a notice of compliance or notice of satisfaction, as the case may
be, has been issued by the ACE administrator or enforcement official.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Civil, Criminal Penalties: Civil penalties cannot be assessed when a
criminal case has been filed for the same date and violation, because fines
will be assessed with the criminal case. However, all other civil and
administrative remedies are available.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Interest: Interest shall be assessed per the city uniform fee schedule
on all outstanding civil penalties, administrative fees, and/or abatement cost
balances until the case has been paid in full.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Fee Schedule: Civil penalties for violations of any provision of this
code or applicable sections of the Utah code shall be assessed pursuant to the
city uniform fee schedule.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Modification: Upon completion of the notice of violation or
administrative code enforcement order, the ALJ may modify the civil penalties
on a finding of good cause. Civil penalties may be waived or modified by the
administrative law judge if there is a finding of good cause based on the
responsible person's claim of legal nonconforming or conditional use, and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The city's verification of the claim; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The responsible person's filing of an application for the
conditional use before expiration of the date to correct and said conditional
use is approved by the city.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Failure To Pay: The failure of any person to pay civil penalties
assessed within the specified time is a violation of this chapter and may
result in the city pursuing any legal remedy to collect the civil penalties as
provided in the law. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10E-5: ABATEMENT OF VIOLATION:
The ACE administrator is authorized to enter upon any property or premises to
abate the violation of this code and applicable sections of the Utah code. The
ACE administrator is authorized to assess all costs for the abatement to the
responsible person and use any remedy available under the law to collect the
costs. If additional abatements are necessary within two (2) years, treble
costs may be assessed against the responsible person(s) for the actual
abatement.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Abatement By City: Once the procedures set forth in this chapter have
been completed, the violation may be abated by city personnel or by a private
contractor acting under the direction of the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Entrance On Private Property: An enforcement official, city personnel,
authorized representative (including a private contractor) may enter upon
private property in a reasonable manner to abate the ordinance violation as
specified in the notice of violation or administrative code enforcement order.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Abatement By Responsible Person; City Costs: If the responsible person
abates the violation before the city performs the actual abatement pursuant to
a notice of violation or administrative code enforcement order, the ACE
administrator may still assess all costs incurred by the city against the
responsible person.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Report: When the abatement is completed, a report describing the work
performed and an itemized account of the total abatement costs shall be
prepared by the ACE administrator. The report shall contain the names and
addresses of the responsible persons of each parcel and the tax parcel number.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Service On Responsible Person: The ACE administrator shall serve the
notice of costs and the itemized bill of costs by registered mail to the last
known address of the responsible person(s). The notice shall demand full
payment within twenty (20) days to the city treasurer.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Costs Hearing: The ACE administrator shall schedule an itemized bill
for costs hearing, if requested in writing by any or all responsible persons.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10E-6: INJUNCTIONS:
In addition to any other remedy provided under this code or applicable sections
of the Utah code, including criminal prosecution or administrative remedies,
any provision of this chapter may be enforced by injunction issued in the
district court upon a suit brought by the city. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
ARTICLE F. COSTS AND FEES
SECTION:
1-10F-1: Declaration Of Purpose
1-10F-2: Costs
1-10F-3: Reinspection Fees
1-10F-4: Administrative Fees
1-10F-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The city council finds that there is a need to recover costs incurred
by enforcement officials, the ACE administrator, the ALJ and other city
personnel who spend considerable time inspecting and reinspecting properties
throughout the city in an effort to ensure compliance with this code or
applicable sections of the Utah code.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The city council further finds that the assessment of costs is an
appropriate method to recover expenses incurred for actual costs of abating
violations, reinspection fees, filing fees, attorney fees, administrative law
judge fees, title search, and any additional actual costs incurred by the city
for each individual case. The assessment and collection of costs shall not
preclude the imposition of any administrative or judicial civil penalties or
fines for violations of this code or applicable sections of the Utah code.
(Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10F-2: COSTS:
Whenever actual costs are incurred by the city on a property to obtain
compliance with provisions of this code and applicable sections of the Utah
code, the ACE administrator may assess costs against the responsible person.
The ACE administrator shall serve the responsible party with a notice of
itemized statement of costs. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10F-3: REINSPECTION FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Notification of reinspection fees shall be provided on the notice of
violation served to the responsible person(s).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Reinspection fees assessed or collected pursuant to this section shall
not be included in any other costs assessed.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The failure of any responsible person to receive a notice of the
reinspection fees shall not affect the validity of any other fees imposed under
this section. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10F-4: ADMINISTRATIVE FEES:
The ACE administrator or ALJ is authorized to assess administrative fees for
costs incurred in the administration of this program, such as investigation of
violations, preparation for hearings, hearings, and the collection process. The
fee assessed shall be the amount set in the city uniform fee schedule. The ACE
administrator shall serve the responsible party with a notice of itemized
statement of fees. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
ARTICLE G. COLLECTION OF PENALTIES, FINES, COSTS AND FEES
SECTION:
1-10G-1: Declaration Of Purpose
1-10G-2: Tax Liens Without Judgment
1-10G-3: Performance Bond
1-10G-4: Writ Of Execution
1-10G-5: Writ Of Garnishment
1-10G-6: Allocation Of Penalties, Fines, Costs And Fees
1-10G-1: DECLARATION OF PURPOSE:
The city council finds that recordation of code enforcement tax liens will
assist in the collection of civil penalties, abatement costs and administrative
fees assessed by the administrative code enforcement hearing program or
judicial orders. The city council further finds that collection of civil
penalties, costs and fees assessed for code enforcement violations is important
in deterring future violations and maintaining the integrity of the city's ACE
program. The procedures established in this article shall be used to complement
existing administrative or judicial remedies that may be pursued to address
violations of this code or applicable state codes. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10G-2: TAX LIENS WITHOUT JUDGMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Itemized Statement: Once the city has abated a property of the
violation, the ACE administrator shall prepare three (3) copies of the itemized
statement of costs incurred in the removal and destruction of the violations
and deliver them to the city treasurer within ten (10) days after completion of
the work of removing the violations.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notice To Property Owner: The ACE administrator shall send, by
registered mail to the property owner's last known address, a copy of the
itemized statement of costs informing him or her that a code enforcement tax
lien is being recorded for the amount of actual costs of abatement. Payment
shall be due within twenty (20) calendar days from the date of mailing.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Lien Recorded: Upon receipt of the itemized statement of costs, the
city treasurer shall record a code enforcement tax lien against the property in
the official records on file in the office of the recorder of Washington
County, state of Utah. The failure of any person with a financial interest in
the property to actually receive the notice of the lien shall not affect the
validity of the lien or any proceedings taken to collect the outstanding costs
of abatement.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Notice Of Satisfaction: Once payment in full is received for the
outstanding civil penalties and costs, or the amount is deemed satisfied
pursuant to a subsequent administrative order, the ACE administrator shall
either record a notice of satisfaction, or provide the property owner or
financial institution with the notice of satisfaction of judgment so that it
can record this notice in the official records on file in the office of the
recorder of Washington County, state of Utah. The notice of satisfaction shall
include the same information as provided for in the original code enforcement
tax lien. Such notice of satisfaction shall cancel the code enforcement tax
lien. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10G-3: PERFORMANCE BOND:
As part of any notice, order or action, the ALJ has the authority to require
responsible persons to post an administrative code enforcement performance bond
to ensure compliance with this chapter, this code, applicable sections of the
Utah code, administrative code enforcement order, or any judicial action. If
the responsible person fails to comply with the notice, order or action, the
bond will be forfeited to the city. The administrative code enforcement
performance bond will not be used to offset the other outstanding costs and
fees associated with the case. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10G-4: WRIT OF EXECUTION:
After obtaining a judgment, the ACE administrator may collect the obligation by
use of all appropriate legal means. This may include the execution on personal
property owned by the responsible person by filing a writ with the applicable
court. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10G-5: WRIT OF GARNISHMENT:
After obtaining a judgment, the ACE administrator may collect the obligation by
use of all appropriate legal means. This may include the garnishment of
paychecks, financial accounts and other income or financial assets by filing a
writ with the applicable court. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)
1-10G-6: ALLOCATION OF PENALTIES, FINES, COSTS AND FEES:
Penalties, fines, costs and fees collected pursuant to this chapter shall be
deposited in the general fund of the city and appropriated and allocated in a
manner determined by the mayor and city council. The city auditor shall
establish accounting procedures to ensure proper account identification, credit
and collection. (Ord. 2014.04, 9-11-2014)

3-1-1: PURPOSE:
This title, adopted pursuant to Utah Code Annotated Title 10, Chapters 1 and 8,
as amended, is enacted for the following purposes: a) to license, regulate and
control businesses within the corporate limits of the City; and b) to assist in
the maintenance of a current index of all businesses within the corporate
limits of the City. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020)

3-1-3: LICENSE OFFICER; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The City Clerk is hereby designated and appointed as ex officio City License
Officer and shall issue licenses in the name of the City to all persons
qualified under the provisions of this Title and shall remit to the Treasurerâ€™s
Office all license fees collected hereunder. In addition to all other powers
granted hereunder, the License Officer or designees shall have the following
powers:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Adopt Forms: Authority to adopt all forms necessary or desirable to
facilitate orderly and systematic issuance of all Business Licenses and ensure
the preservation of business records.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Investigation of Applicants: Authority to authorize investigation of
any applicant or Licensee, either at the time of issuance of a license, or at
any reasonable time thereafter, in order to determine the eligibility of such
applicant or Licensee for the issuance or renewal of a Business License. The
License Officer may engage the help and services of appropriate law enforcement
and public safety agencies, public utility providers or other City departments
for purposes of conducting such investigations.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Inspection of Premises and Records: Inspect proposed or existing places
of business to ensure compliance with building, safety and health codes and
inspect books and records of any applicant for the administration and
enforcement of this Title; provided, however, that any such inspection of
premises or business records shall be at reasonable times and upon prior notice
to the applicant or Licensee.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Determination of Standing of Applicant Or Licensee: Make a
determination whether the applicant or Licensee is in violation of any
provision of any ordinance of the City, or indebted or obligated in any manner
to the City or any department thereof, or in violation of any City land use
regulation (Toquerville City Code Title 10 - Toquerville Land Management Code)
by reason of the condition of the business premises or the use to be made
thereof.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Require Necessary Affidavits: When considered necessary in the
discretion of the License Officer, require affidavits regarding the prior
history of the applicant, indicating whether such person has had prior business
experience, has had a prior business license revoked or suspended, or any other
information with respect to the applicantâ€™s prior experience or personal
integrity, including a record of prior convictions or arrests of the applicant
or Licensee.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Issuance of Notice of Acceptance or Rejection: Notify any applicant or
Licensee of the acceptance or rejection of the application for a Business
License or the renewal of a Business License, and, in the event of rejection,
said notice shall state in writing the reasons for such rejection. The License
Officer shall also have authority to notify the Licensee of any facts
constituting a violation of any ordinance of the City.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Enforcement: Be responsible for coordinating the enforcement of all
provisions of this Title, and shall cause to be filed complaints against all
persons or entities violating any of the provisions of this Title. (Ord.
2020.14, 7-16-2020; amd. Ord. 2022-01, 1-19-2022)
3-1-4: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for any person or entity, either directly or
indirectly, to engage in Business within the corporate limits of the City
without having first obtained a Business License, whether such License shall be
a new license or a renewal license, and without having first paid the
applicable license fee in accordance with all provisions of this Title.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any person or entity engaging in bona fide agricultural activities and
selling the produce thereof shall be exempt from the requirement to obtain a
Business License. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020)
3-1-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; RENEWAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Information Required: It shall be the responsibility of any person or
entity engaging in Business within the City to voluntarily apply for an initial
Business License. The application shall be submitted to the License Officer on
a form provided by the City which shall contain the following information:
business name, general description of business to be engaged in, mailing
address, phone number, date of birth, social security number, all names of
individuals involved in the ownership of the Business and such other
information as the License Officer shall deem reasonable and necessary.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Application Voided: A Business License application that has not had all
required items submitted and approved and the license issued within six (6)
months of application date shall be considered void and a new application and
fee will be required.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Renewal: Any person or entity holding an active Business License,
except where otherwise specified in this Title, shall be granted the
opportunity to obtain a renewal license. The License Officer shall issue
notices of renewal to eligible businesses forty five (45) days before the
expiration date on such form as the licensing officer may direct. Any Licensee
wishing to obtain a renewal license shall verify the accuracy of the
information regarding the business as requested on the renewal form and shall
attest to the accuracy of said information by affixing his/her signature to the
form. The signed renewal form shall be returned with the appropriate license
renewal fee to the License Officer. Any Licensee no longer engaging in business
within the City limits and therefore not wishing to obtain a renewal license
shall indicate such intentions on the renewal form, attesting with his/her
signature, and return such form to the License Officer. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-
2020; Ord. 2024.09, 6-20-2024)

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Rebate of Fee: No rebate or refund of any license fee or part thereof

Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Initial Applications and Renewal Applications: A Business License shall

regardless of when they are submitted.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Inspections Made: Notwithstanding the provisions of Subsection A of
this Section, no license shall be granted and validly in force until any and
all required inspections have been made, all City administrative approvals have
been given, and all licensing and delinquency related fees (including any such
unpaid fees from prior years) are paid by the applicant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Payment Date On Renewal Licenses: Except as provided in Subsection D,
of this Section, annual business licensing fees shall be due and payable on or
before December 31 of the year immediately prior to year for which the Business
License is applicable and in force; and shall become delinquent if not paid, in
full, prior to March 1 of the year in which the Business License is applicable
and in force.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Payment Date On Initial Licenses: Payment for initial Business Licenses
are due and payable at the time of application therefor; and no license shall
be issued until such payment is made. There is no grace period for the payment
of such fees wherein business may lawfully be transacted.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Delinquency Fees, Civil Penalty And Collection Costs:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Delinquency Related Fees: Delinquency related fees shall mean and
include any fees and costs provided for in this Section 7.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Late Fees: Any license not renewed and paid for (in full) prior to
December 31, shall incur a late fee, which shall be established by resolution
and which may be changed from time to time and set forth in the Cityâ€™s uniform
fee schedule. No license may be issued until all Delinquency Related Fees are
paid in full.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Enforcement: The failure to pay fees by March 1, shall result in a
prior license being non-renewable. If the applicant wishes to continue engaging
in business, the applicant will need to re-apply for a new business license and
the following shall be performed before an applicant may lawfully transact
business within the City again:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Applicant must submit to the City a new business license application
and any necessary documents as may be required by the City License Officer
pursuant to Section
3-1-5 , above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Applicant must pay the license fee prescribed by Section
3-1-6  above, as well as any Delinquency Related Fees, including Late Fees and
licensing fees due during any lapse in licensure while the applicant continued
to Engage in Business.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Applicant must subject itself any the proposed Place of Business to
be inspected for compliance with all building, safety and health codes adopted
by the City pursuant to Section
3-1-3 (C) above.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Applicant must repay the City all enforcement costs incurred by the
City or otherwise attributable to the applicantâ€™s prior delinquency and/or
illegal conduct, including all costs and reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by
the City. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020; amd. Ord. 2021.05, 4-21-2021; Ord. 2023.24,
11-15-2023)
3-1-8: BUSINESS LICENSE CERTIFICATES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Content: All Business License Certificates shall be signed by the
License Officer and shall contain the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The name of the person to whom such Business License has been

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The amount paid.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The type of Business.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The date of expiration.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The place where such Business, calling, trade or profession is to be

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Display: Every Business License certificate issued under this Title
