3-1-9: TRANSFER OF LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No Business License granted or issued under this Title shall be assigned or
transferred to any other person or entity. It shall not be deemed to authorize
any person or entity other than the person or entity named therein to do
Business or to authorize any other business, calling, trade or profession than
is named therein. No Business License issued pursuant to this Title may be
transferred to any location not named therein without the Licensee first having
applied for a change in business location on such form as directed by the
License Officer. A new application fee shall be required to process the
application. If the address change occurs at time of renewal, only the regular
renewal fee shall be assessed. Upon approval of a business location change, the
License Officer will issue a new Business License certificate showing the
approved location and shall thereby nullify the previously issued License.
(Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020)
3-1-10: BRANCH ESTABLISHMENTS:
A separate License must be obtained for each separate Place of Business in the
City and each Business License shall authorize the Licensee to engage only in
the Business licensed thereby at the location or in the manner designated in
the Business License certificate; provided, that warehouses and distributing
places used in connection with or incident to a Business licensed under this
Title shall not be deemed to be separate Places of Business or branch
establishments. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020)
3-1-11: RECIPROCAL RECOGNITION; DELIVERY OF GOODS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No Business License shall be required for operation of any vehicle or
equipment in the City when:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Such vehicle is merely passing through the City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Such vehicle is used exclusively in intercity or interstate
commerce.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No Business License shall be required by this Title of any person whose
only business activity in the City is the mere delivery in the City of property
sold by him/her/it at a regular Place of Business maintained outside the City
where:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Such person's Business is at the time of such delivery licensed by
the Utah municipality or county in which such Place of Business is situated;
and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The authority licensing such Business grants to licensees of the
City making deliveries within its jurisdiction the same privileges, upon
substantially the same terms, as are granted by this Section; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Neither the property delivered nor any of the facilities by which it
was manufactured, produced, processed or stored are located within the City or
are subject to inspection by authority of the City for compliance with health
or sanitary standards prescribed by the City.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The License Officer shall, at the request of any person, certify a copy
of this Section to any municipality or county of the state to which a copy has
not previously been certified. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020; amd. Ord. 2021.03, 2-
17-2021)
3-1-12: REVOCATION OR DENIAL OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Conditions: Any Business License issued pursuant to the provisions of
this Title or of any other ordinance of the City may be revoked and any
application denied by the City because of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The failure of the Licensee or applicant to comply with the
conditions and requirements of this Title or any other ordinance of the City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Unlawful activities conducted or permitted on the premises where the
Business is conducted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Fraud, misrepresentation or a false statement contained in the
application for the license.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of
carrying on the business.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notice To Licensee: Prior to the revocation of a Business license,
denial of a new application, or denial of an application to renew a Business
License, the Licensee or applicant shall be given written notice which shall
state in substance that the City Council intends to consider revocation of the
Business License, deny the new application, or deny the application to renew,
together with the reason or reasons therefor, at a regular or special meeting
of the City Council, and that the Licensee or applicant has a right to appear,
to be represented by counsel, to hear the evidence against him, to cross
examine witnesses and to present evidence as to why the license should not be
revoked or the renewal application denied. The regular or special meeting of
the City Council shall be at least ten (10) days and not more than thirty (30)
days from the date such notice is sent. This Subsection shall not apply to
applications for licenses for Businesses which have not previously been
licensed by the City, and such applicants need only be informed that their
application has been denied and the reason(s) therefore. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-
2020)
3-1-13: VIOLATIONS CRIMINAL; CIVIL PENALTIES:
Any person failing or refusing to comply with any requirements of this Title,
or violating any of the provisions of this Title, or knowingly misrepresenting
to the License Officer or authorized agent any material fact in procuring any
Business License or renewal thereof, or who fails or refuses to comply with or
violates any of the conditions or restrictions of any Business License issued
hereunder, shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor for each day such violation
shall continue and shall also be subject to all civil penalty provisions
provided in the ordinances of the City. (Ord. 2020.14, 7-16-2020)
CHAPTER 2
TAXES
ARTICLE A. SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:
3-2A-1: Title
3-2A-2: Purpose
3-2A-3: Tax Imposed; Compliance With Statute; Exclusions
3-2A-1: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the SALES AND USE TAX ORDINANCE OF TOQUERVILLE
CITY. (2014 Code)
3-2A-2: PURPOSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The 48th session of the Utah legislature has authorized the counties
and municipalities of the state to enact sales and use tax ordinances imposing
a one percent (1%) tax.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â It is the purpose of this chapter to conform the sales and use tax of
the city to the requirements of the sales and use tax act, Utah Code Annotated
title 59, chapter 12, as currently amended. (2014 Code)
3-2A-3: TAX IMPOSED; COMPLIANCE WITH STATUTE; EXCLUSIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Sales Tax: From and after the effective date hereof, there is levied
and there shall be collected and paid a tax upon every retail sale of tangible
personal property, services and meals made within the city at the rate of one
percent (1%).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Excise Tax: An excise tax is hereby imposed on the storage, use or
other consumption in this city of tangible personal property from any retailer
on or after the operative date hereof at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
sales price of the property.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Determine Place Of Business: For the purpose of this chapter, all
retail sales shall be presumed to have been consummated at the place of
business delivered by the retailer or his agent to an out of state destination
or to a common carrier for delivery to an out of state destination. In the
event a retailer has no permanent place of business, the place or places at
which the retail sales are consummated shall be as determined under the rules
and regulations prescribed by and adopted by the state tax commission. Public
utilities, as defined by Utah Code Annotated title 54, shall not be obligated
to determine the place or places within any county or municipality where public
utilities services are rendered, but the place of sale or the sales tax revenue
arising from such service allocable to the city shall be determined by the
state tax commission pursuant to an appropriate formula and other rules and
regulations to be prescribed and adopted by it.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Statute Adopted: Except as hereinafter provided, and except insofar as
they are inconsistent with the provisions of the sales and use tax act, all of
the provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, as amended and in
force and effect on the effective date hereof, insofar as they relate to sales
taxes, are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as though fully set
forth herein.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Substitution Of Terms In Statute: Wherever, and to the extent that in
Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, the state of Utah is named or
referred to as the taxing agency, the name of this city shall be substituted
therefor. Nothing in subsection D of this section shall be deemed to require
substitution of the name of the city for the word "state" when that word is
used as part of the title of the state tax commission, or of the constitution
of the state, nor shall the name of the city be substituted for that of the
state in any section when the result of that substitution would require action
to be taken by or against the city or any agency thereof, rather than by or
against the state tax commission in performing the functions incident to the
administration or operation of the chapter.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Additional License Not Required: If an annual license has been issued
to retailer under Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-106, an additional license
shall not be required by reason of this chapter.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Exclusions: There shall be excluded from the purchase price paid or
charged by which the tax is measured:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The amount of any sales or use tax imposed by the state upon a
retailer or consumer;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The gross receipts from the sale of or the cost of storage, use or
other consumption of tangible personal property upon which a sales or use tax
has become due by reason of the sale transaction to any other municipality and
any county in the state, under the sales or use tax ordinance enacted by that
county or municipality in accordance with the sales and use tax act. (2014
Code)
ARTICLE B. TRANSIENT ROOM TAX
SECTION:
3-2B-1: Definitions
3-2B-2: Tax Imposed
3-2B-3: Computation Of Gross Receipts; Exclusions
3-2B-4: Collection And Remittance Procedures
3-2B-5: Use Of Revenues
3-2B-6: Contract With State
3-2B-7: Tax Rate Changes
3-2B-8: Penalty
3-2B-1: DEFINITIONS:
All definitions found in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-102, the sales and
use tax act, are hereby adopted and incorporated into this article by
reference. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007; amd. 2014 Code)
3-2B-2: TAX IMPOSED:
There is levied upon the business of every person, company, corporation or
other like and similar persons, groups or organizations, doing business in the
city as motor courts, motels, hotels, inns, campgrounds, RV parks, or like and
similar public accommodations, an annual license tax equal to one percent (1%)
of the gross revenue derived from the rent for each and every occupancy of a
suite, room or rooms, space or spaces, for a period of less than thirty (30)
consecutive days ("transient room tax"). The above tax shall apply to any
person, company, corporation or other like and similar persons, groups or
organizations doing business in an area annexed into the city municipal
boundaries after the enactment of this article. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007; amd.
2014 Code)
3-2B-3: COMPUTATION OF GROSS RECEIPTS; EXCLUSIONS:
For purposes of this article, gross receipts shall be computed upon the base
room or space rental rate assessed to the actual occupants. There shall be
excluded from the gross revenue, by which this tax is measured:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The amount of any sales or use tax imposed by the state or by any other
governmental agency upon a retailer or consumer;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The amount of any transient room tax or resort communities tax levied
under the authority of Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, parts 3 and 4,
as amended, or its successor;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Receipts from the sale or service charge for any food, beverage or room
service charges in conjunction with the occupancy of the suite, room or rooms,
not included in the base room or space rental rate; and
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Charges made for supplying telephone service, gas or electrical energy
service, not included in the base room or space rental rate. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-
8-2007)
3-2B-4: COLLECTION AND REMITTANCE PROCEDURES:
In collecting the transient room tax, the city will administer, collect and
enforce said tax in compliance with parts 1 and 2 of the Utah sales and use tax
act 1  ("tax act") and with the general taxation policies adopted by the state
tax commission. Commencing upon the effective date hereof, the transient room
tax imposed by this article shall be due and payable to the city treasurer
quarterly on or before the last day of the month next succeeding each calendar
quarterly period. Every person or business taxed hereunder shall, on or before
the last day of the month next succeeding each calendar quarterly period, file
with the city treasurer a report of its gross revenue for the preceding
quarterly period. The report shall be accompanied by a remittance of the amount
of tax due for the period covered by the report. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007)
Â 
Notes
1 1. UCA Â§ 59-12-101 et seq.
3-2B-5: USE OF REVENUES:
The transient room tax imposed by this article shall be used by the city for
promotion of the city and its recreational, tourist and cultural facilities,
activities and events. Notwithstanding the preceding sentence, the revenue
generated from the levy of the transient room tax may also be used for any
general fund purpose as deemed acceptable by the city council pursuant to Utah
Code Annotated section 59-12-352. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007)
3-2B-6: CONTRACT WITH STATE:
The city shall contract with the state tax commission or other agencies to
perform all functions incident to the administration and operation of this
article, including the assessment and collection of said tax. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-
8-2007; amd. 2014 Code)
3-2B-7: TAX RATE CHANGES:
In the event the city desires to enlarge, repeal or modify the transient room
tax authorized pursuant to this article, the city may do so only after giving
notice of said change to the state tax commission and shall become effective
upon the first allowable date prescribed in Utah Code Annotated section 59-12-
355. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007)
3-2B-8: PENALTY:
In addition to all remedies for noncompliance afforded to the city pursuant to
the tax act, a party's failure to timely remit to the city treasurer any
transient room tax owed under this article or to properly disclose the amount
of tax due, or any other violation of this article, shall be a class B
misdemeanor for each offense, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2007-03, 3-8-2007; amd. 2014 Code)
ARTICLE C. MUNICIPAL ENERGY SALES AND USE TAX
SECTION:

3-2C-1: INTENT:
It is the intent of the city to adopt the municipal energy sales and use tax,
pursuant to, and in conformance with, Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-301 et
seq., the municipal energy sales and use tax act. (Ord. 2009.04, 6-18-2009)
3-2C-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
CONSUMER: A person who acquires taxable energy for any use that is subject to
the city municipal energy sales and use tax.
CONTRACTUAL FRANCHISE FEE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A fee:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Provided for in a franchise agreement; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â That is consideration for the franchise agreement; or
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A fee similar to subsection A1 of this definition; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any combination of subsections A1 and A2 of this definition.
DELIVERED VALUE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The fair market value of the taxable energy delivered for sale or use
in the city and includes:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The value of the energy itself; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any transportation, freight, customer demand charges, services
charges or other costs typically incurred in providing taxable energy in usable
form to each class of customer in the city.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Delivered value does not include the amount of a tax paid under:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 1 or part 2; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Utah Code Annotated title 10, chapter 1, part 3.
ENERGY SUPPLIER: A person supplying taxable energy, except for persons
supplying a de minimis amount of taxable energy, if such persons are excluded
by rule promulgated by the state tax commission.
FRANCHISE AGREEMENT: A franchise or an ordinance, contract or agreement
granting a franchise.
FRANCHISE TAX:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A franchise tax;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A tax similar to a franchise tax; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any combination of subsection A or B of this definition.
PERSON: Includes any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association,
corporation, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, syndicate, this state,
any county, city, municipality, district or other local governmental entity of

Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Installment and credit sales;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any closed transaction constituting a sale;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Any transaction under which right to acquire, use or consume taxable
energy is granted under a lease or contract and the transfer would be taxable

TAXABLE ENERGY: Gas and electricity.
USE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The exercise of any right or power over taxable energy incident to the

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Does not include the sale, display, demonstration or trial of the
taxable energy in the regular course of business and held for resale. (Ord.
2009.04, 6-18-2009)
3-2C-3: TAX IMPOSED:
There is hereby levied, subject to the provisions of this article, a tax on
every sale or use of taxable energy made within the city equaling six percent
(6%) of the delivered value of the taxable energy to the consumer. This tax
shall be known as the municipal energy sales and use tax.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Calculation: The tax shall be calculated on the delivered value of the
taxable energy to the consumer.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Additional Tax: The tax shall be in addition to any sales or use tax on
taxable energy imposed by the city or state as authorized by Utah Code
Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 2, the local sales and use tax act. (Ord.
2009.04, 6-18-2009)
3-2C-4: EXEMPTIONS FROM TAX:
No exemptions are granted from the municipal energy sales and use tax, except
as expressly provided in Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-305; notwithstanding
an exemption granted under Utah Code Annotated title 59, chapter 12, part 1,
tax collection. (Ord. 2009.04, 6-18-2009; amd. 2014 Code)
3-2C-5: CONTRACT WITH STATE TAX COMMISSION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Required; Authority Of Mayor: On or before the effective date hereof,

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Monthly Payments By Supplier; Conditions: An energy supplier shall pay

($1,000,000.00) or more; and

tax.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Deduction Of Franchise Fees: An energy supplier paying the municipal

2009)

3-2D-1: DEFINITIONS:

3-2D-2: LEVY OF TAX:
There is hereby levied a municipal telecommunications license tax on the gross
receipts from telecommunications service attributed to the city (otherwise
known as the gross receipts attributed to the municipality). (Ord. 2009.05, 6-
18-2009)
3-2D-3: TAX RATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The rate of the tax levy shall be three and one-half percent (3.5%) of
the telecommunication provider's gross receipts from telecommunications service
that are attributed to the municipality, subject to the provisions of
subsection B of this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â If the location of a transaction for telecommunications service is
determined to be a municipality other than the city, then the rate imposed on
the gross receipts for telecommunications services shall be the lower of: 1)
the rate imposed by the taxing jurisdiction in which the transaction is
located; or 2) the rate for the nonmobile telecommunication services shall be
the rate imposed by the municipality in which the customer's service address is
located; or 3) for mobile telecommunications service, the rate imposed by the
municipality of the customer's primary place of use. (Ord. 2009.05, 6-18-2009)
3-2D-4: RATE LIMITATION AND EXEMPTION:
The rate of this levy shall not exceed three and one-half percent (3.5%) of the
telecommunication provider's gross receipts from telecommunication service
attributed to the municipality unless a higher rate is approved by a majority
vote of the voters in the city that vote in:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A municipal general election;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A regular general election; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A local special election. (Ord. 2009.05, 6-18-2009)
3-2D-5: EFFECTIVE DATE OF TAX LEVY:
This tax shall be levied beginning the earlier of October 1, 2009, or the first
day of any calendar quarter after a ninety (90) day period beginning on the
date the commission received or receives notice pursuant to Utah Code Annotated
section 10-1-403, as amended, of the enactment of this article. (Ord. 2009.05,
6-18-2009)
3-2D-6: CHANGES IN RATE OR REPEAL OF TAX:
Any changes to the tax rate or a repeal of the tax levied under this article
are subject to the requirement of Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-403. If the
tax rate is changed or the tax repealed, then the appropriate notice shall be
given as provided in Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-403. (Ord. 2009.05, 6-18-
2009)
3-2D-7: INTERLOCAL AGREEMENT FOR COLLECTION:
On or before the effective date hereof, the city shall enter into a uniform
interlocal agreement with the commission as described in Utah Code Annotated
section 10-1-405, as amended, for the collection, enforcement and
administration of this municipal telecommunications license tax. (Ord. 2009.05,
6-18-2009)
3-2D-8: TAXES ERRONEOUSLY RECOVERED FROM CUSTOMERS:
Pursuant to the provisions of Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-408, a customer
may not bring a cause of action against a telecommunications provider on the
basis that the telecommunications provider erroneously recovered from the
customer the municipal telecommunications license tax, except as provided in
Utah Code Annotated section 10-1-408. (Ord. 2009.05, 6-18-2009)
3-2D-9: REPEAL OF INCONSISTENT TAXES AND FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any tax or fee previously enacted by this municipality for the purpose
of taxation of telecommunication services under authority of Utah Code
Annotated section 10-1-203 or Utah Code Annotated title 11, chapter 26, local
taxation of utilities limitation, is hereby repealed.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to repeal any municipal
ordinance or fee which provides that the city may recover from a
telecommunications provider, the management costs of the city caused by the
activities of the telecommunications provider in the rights of way of the
municipality, if the fee is imposed in accordance with Utah Code Annotated
section 72-7-102, as amended, and is not related to the municipality's loss of
use of a highway as a result of the activities of the telecommunications
provider in a right of way, or increased deterioration of a highway as a result
of the activities of the telecommunications provider in a right of way.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to repeal or limit the
city right to charge fees or taxes on persons not subject to the municipal
telecommunications license tax under this article who locate telecommunications
facilities, as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 72-7-108, as amended,
within the jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. 2009.05, 6-18-2009)

3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
The words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings specified in
the Utah alcoholic beverage control act, Utah Code Annotated title 32B, as
amended, unless a different meaning is clearly evident. (2014 Code)
3-3-2: TYPES OF RETAIL LICENSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: Retail licenses issued hereunder shall be of the following
kinds and shall carry the following privileges and be known as:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Class A (consumption off premises beer license); and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Class B (consumption on premises beer license).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Class A: A class A license (consumption off premises beer license)
shall entitle the licensee to sell beer on the licensed premises in the
original containers for consumption off the licensed premises in accordance
with the state alcoholic beverage control act and the ordinances of the city.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Class B: A class B license (consumption on premises beer license) shall
entitle the licensee to sell beer in the original containers or on draft on the
licensed premises for consumption on the licensed premises; or sell beer on the
licensed premises in sealed containers for consumption off premises in
accordance with the Utah alcoholic beverage control act. Total sales from beer
are not to exceed fifty percent (50%) of the business's gross sales. (2014
Code)
3-3-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â License Required; Penalty: It is a class B misdemeanor, subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, for any person to engage in the business of selling beer at
retail, in bottles, cans or draft, without first having procured a license
therefor from the governing body and paid the license fee required by this
chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Sales After Revocation Prohibited: It is a class B misdemeanor, subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, for any person to sell beer after the revocation of the
license issued pursuant to this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Separate License; Transferability; Compliance: A separate license shall
be required for each place of sale and the license shall at all times be
conspicuously displayed in the place to which it shall refer or for which it
shall be issued. All licensees shall comply with the Utah alcoholic beverage
control act and the regulations of the Utah alcoholic beverage control
commission. (2014 Code)
3-3-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Requirements: All applications for licenses authorized by this chapter
shall be verified and shall be filed with the city recorder. The application
must state the applicant's name in full and that he understands and has read
and complied with the requirements and possesses the qualifications specified
in the Utah alcoholic beverage control act and this chapter. If the applicant
is a copartnership, the names and addresses of all partners; if a limited
liability company, the names and addresses of all members and managers; and if
a corporation, the names and addresses of all officers and directors, must be
stated.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Subscribed By Applicant: The application must be subscribed by the
applicant who shall state under oath that the facts therein contained are true.
(2014 Code)
3-3-5: FEE FOR LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: In addition to any other business license fee which any
person or place of business may be required to pay, there is imposed on the
business location of every person engaged in the sale or dispensing of beer a
license fee as established by the city council.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Fee To Accompany Application: Applications provided for in this chapter
shall be accompanied by the fee provided in this chapter. The fee shall be
returned to the applicant if the application is denied. (2014 Code)
3-3-6: QUALIFICATIONS OF LICENSEE:
No license shall be granted to any retailer to sell beer within the city unless
he shall be of good moral character, over the age of twenty one (21) years, and
a citizen of the United States, or to anyone who has been convicted of a felony
or of any violation of any law of the state or provision of the ordinances of
the city relating to intoxicating liquors, or of keeping a gambling or
disorderly house, or who has pleaded guilty to or has forfeited his bail on a
charge of having committed a felony or of having violated any such law or
ordinance, or to any partnership, any member of which lacks any of the
qualifications herein set forth in this chapter, or to any corporation, of
which any stockholder, holding at least twenty percent (20%) of the total
issued and outstanding stock of the applicant corporation, director or officer
lacks any such qualifications. (2014 Code)
3-3-7: REFERRAL TO PLANNING AND ZONING DIRECTOR:
All applications filed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall
be referred to the planning and zoning director for inspection and report. The
planning and zoning director shall, when possible within ten (10) days after
receiving such application, make report to the governing body of the general
reputation and character of the persons who habitually frequent such place; the
nature and kind of business conducted at such place by the applicant or by any
other person or by the applicant at any other place; whether the place is or
has been conducted in a lawful, quiet and orderly manner; the nature and kind
of entertainment, if any, at such place; whether gambling is or has been
permitted on the premises or by the applicant at any other place; and the
proximity of such premises to any school or church. The planning and zoning
director shall also add to such report his recommendation as to whether or not
the application should be granted. (2014 Code)
3-3-8: BOND REQUIRED:
No license required by this chapter shall be granted by the governing body
until the applicant shall have filed with the city recorder a bond in the sum
of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) payable to the city. (2014 Code)
3-3-9: HEALTH DEPARTMENT PERMIT:
No license under this chapter shall be issued until the applicant therefor
shall have first procured from the health department a permit which shall show
that the premises to be licensed is in a sanitary condition and that the
equipment used in the storage, distribution or sale of beer complies with all
the health regulations of the city and the state. (2014 Code)
3-3-10: TRANSFERABILITY:
Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be transferable, and if
revoked by the governing body, the fee paid by the licensee to the city for the
license shall be forfeited to the city. (2014 Code)
3-3-11: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Time For Renewal: All applications for renewal licenses filed by the
holders of existing licenses shall be filed with the city recorder at least
thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date of the then issued license. Any
person who fails to file such application within the time limit shall close his
licensed premises on the expiration date of the then issued license and shall
keep the premises closed for any and all business for the sale of beer until
the date his new license is issued by the governing body.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Revocation For Nonuse: If the holder of an existing beer license has
not used the beer license (by the selling of beer) for a period of six (6)
months or more, during any one calendar year, the beer license will
automatically be revoked. (2014 Code)
3-3-12: PURCHASE OF BEER FOR RESALE:
It is a class B misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, for any licensee to purchase or acquire, or to have or
possess for the purpose of sale or distribution, any beer, except that which he
shall have lawfully purchased from a brewer or wholesaler licensed under the
provisions of the Utah alcoholic beverage control act. (2014 Code)
3-3-13: OPERATIONAL RESTRICTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person to sell beer at any public dance, fair or
celebration, or to any person intoxicated, or under the influence of any
intoxicating beverage. It is unlawful for any person to sell beer in any dance
hall or theater.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No license shall be granted to sell beer in any dance hall, theater, or
within six hundred (600) yards of any church or within six hundred (600) yards
of any school.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â It is unlawful to sell beer to any person under the age of twenty one
(21), or to permit the drinking of liquor on such premises.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Licensed premises shall be kept brightly illuminated at all times while
they are occupied or open for business, and no booth or kind of stall shall be
maintained unless all tables, chairs and occupants are kept open to full view
from the main floor and the entrance of such licensed premises. It is unlawful
to advertise the sale of beer except under such regulations as are made by the
state alcoholic beverage control commission; provided, that a simple
designation of the fact that beer is sold under city license may be placed in
or upon the window or front of the licensed premises.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â It is unlawful for any person to sell beer except in the manner for
which he has been so licensed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (2014
Code)
3-3-14: SUNDAY SALES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person having a license for the sale of beer to sell,
barter, distribute, give away, exchange, dispense or serve beer on the first
day of the week commonly known as Sunday. (2014 Code)
3-3-15: INSPECTIONS AUTHORIZED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All licensed premises shall be subject to inspection by any officer,
agent or peace officer of the city, or the alcoholic beverage control
commission, or the health department, and every licensee shall, at the request
of the health department, furnish to it samples of beer which he shall have for
sale.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Any license granted pursuant to this chapter may be revoked on a
finding by the governing body that the licensee has had ten (10) days' or more
notice from the health department that the licensee is violating one or more
health ordinances, rules or regulations of the city or of the state division of
health and has failed to comply with such health ordinances, rules or
regulations.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The governing body may direct the law enforcement officers to close
down any business licensed under this chapter where the health department has
determined that continued operation of the business presents an imminent danger
to the health of the community or persons who may eat or drink at the business.
(2014 Code)
3-3-16: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Authority: The governing body may, after a hearing, revoke or suspend
any beer license on a finding by it that the licensee or his officers, agents
or employees have violated any provision of this chapter or any ordinance of
the city, whether now or hereafter enacted, which in any way relates to the
operation of the business or the safety of the public.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Hearing: A hearing may be requested by any person:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Who is denied or refused a beer license by any officer, agent or
employee of the city;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Whose beer license is revoked, restricted, qualified or limited from
that for which it was first issued.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Request For Hearing: The request for hearing must be made in writing to
the mayor or city recorder and made within thirty (30) days following the date
the notice denying, refusing, revoking, qualifying or restricting the beer
license is mailed by the city to the applicant or license holder at his address
as it appears on the application or license.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Notice Of Hearing: Following receipt of a request for hearing, the
governing body shall inform the person requesting a hearing of the time and
place the hearing is to be held. At the hearing, the aggrieved party shall have
the right to hear and examine any witnesses the city may produce to support its
decision and to present his own evidence in support of his contention. The
governing body shall, within ten (10) days following the conclusion of the
hearing, in writing, inform the person who requested the hearing of the
decision of the city council.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Limitation: This section shall not be construed so as to afford any
aggrieved party more than one hearing before the city council, nor shall the
hearing provided in this section apply to any criminal complaint or proceeding.
(2014 Code)
CHAPTER 4
COMMERCIAL CHEMICAL APPLICATORS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Definitions
3-4-2: Issuance Or Renewal Of License
3-4-3: Chemical Vehicle Requirements
3-4-4: Repair And Maintenance Of Equipment
3-4-5: Testing And Inspections
3-4-6: Records Maintained
3-4-7: Violations
3-4-8: Suspension Of License
3-4-9: Restitution
3-4-10: Penalty
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this
section:
BACKFLOW: The reversal of the normal flow of water in a potable water
distribution system as a result of cross connection.
BACKFLOW ADMINISTRATOR: A certified level 1 backflow administrator employed or
approved by the city or the Washington County water conservancy district.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE OR ASSEMBLY: A device, assembly or means designed to
prevent backflow, which complies with the specifications of section 608 of the
international plumbing code.
CHEMICAL: Any solid, gas, liquid or other substance of whatever nature which is
possible to introduce into the public drinking water system, other than the
intended potable water, including, but not limited to, nonpotable water,
pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, soaps, detergents and other similar
substances.
CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT: Any equipment, device or other contraption of whatever
nature which is used or designed for the handling, storage, transportation or
application of chemicals, including, but not limited to, herbicide, pesticide,
fertilizer, mobile wash and other similar equipment.
CHEMICAL VEHICLE: Every vehicle of whatever nature used or designed for the
handling, storage, transportation or application of chemicals, including, but
not limited to, herbicide, pesticide, fertilizer, mobile wash and other similar
vehicles.
CITY WATER SYSTEM: Each and every component of the city municipal water supply
and delivery system, including, for purposes of this chapter, those portions of
the Washington County water conservancy district system within the
jurisdictional boundaries of the city.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any actual or potential connection between a potable water
system and any other source or system through which it is possible to introduce
into the public drinking water system any used water, industrial fluid, gas or
substance, other than the intended potable water. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012; amd.
2014 Code)
3-4-2: ISSUANCE OR RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
The issuance or renewal of a business license for any business employing
chemical equipment or vehicles subject to the provisions of this chapter may be
conditioned upon compliance with this chapter, and any failure to comply with
this chapter shall be grounds for suspension of a business license issued to
any such business. At the time of issuance or renewal of a business license,
the owner of any such vehicle or equipment shall provide to the business
licensing department the current authorization issued by the backflow
administrator. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-3: CHEMICAL VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Vehicle Requires Backflow Device: Every chemical vehicle to which water
is or potentially may be added from the city and/or the Washington County water
conservancy district system shall be equipped with a permanently affixed and
operational air gap backflow device, and all water added to such vehicles shall
pass through a backflow device.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Equipment Requires Backflow Device: No person shall add water to any
chemical equipment via a hose, pump or other equipment unless such hose, pump
or other equipment is fitted with an effective and approved permanently affixed
backflow prevention device or assembly to prevent backflow of chemicals or
liquids into the city water system, streams, lakes, other sources of water or
other areas. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-4: REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE OF EQUIPMENT:
The maintenance, including necessary repairs, of all backflow prevention
devices or assemblies and cross connection control devices required by this
chapter shall be the responsibility of the owner of the vehicle and/or
equipment where an assembly or device is installed, and failure to adequately
maintain any required device or assembly shall be a violation hereof. (Ord.
2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-5: TESTING AND INSPECTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Access Required: All equipment and vehicles on which a backflow
prevention device or assembly is required shall be open for inspection at all
reasonable times by authorized representatives of the water service department
in order to determine whether cross connections or sanitary hazards, including
violations of this chapter, exist. In order to make such determinations, the
inspection shall include access to any vehicle and equipment where cross
connections might exist. The owner and any occupant shall be responsible to
provide access for inspection purposes.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Annual Testing And Inspection Of Chemical Vehicles: Each owner of
chemical equipment or vehicles on which a backflow prevention device or
assembly is required under this chapter, shall have certified inspections made
of each backflow device before it is put into service and at least once a year
thereafter at the owner's expense by a backflow administrator. Where the city
deems the hazard to be great, the city may require such inspections and tests
at a more frequent interval as prescribed by the city. All such tests shall be
made according to the applicable standards set forth by the state and the
international plumbing code. The backflow administrator shall issue and place
the approved sticker onto the vehicle and/or chemical equipment in a visible
location. The city may require proof of compliance with this subsection at any
time, which shall be fulfilled by presenting the vehicle and/or chemical
equipment with the sticker issued and placed by the backflow administrator. It
shall be the responsibility of the owner of any such vehicle or equipment to
arrange for the inspections required by this subsection. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-
2012)
3-4-6: RECORDS MAINTAINED:
The water department shall keep records of cross connection hazards and the
condition of backflow prevention devices or assemblies, including those records
required by state and federal agencies. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-7: VIOLATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Specified: A violation of this chapter exists if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Failure To Install: A backflow prevention assembly and/or device
required by this chapter for control of cross connections is not installed or
maintained, as required in this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Removal Or Bypass Of Assembly And/Or Device: It is found that a
backflow prevention assembly and/or device is removed or bypassed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Unprotected Cross Connection: An unprotected cross connection exists
on the vehicle and/or equipment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Failure To Inspect: The periodic system inspection required herein
has not been conducted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â False Report Or False Information: A false report or false
information is provided to the city by or on behalf of the owner or consumer,
with regard to the cross connection or backflow prevention assembly and/or
device.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Failure To Obtain Sticker: The current sticker is not on the vehicle
and/or chemical equipment in a visible location.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notice Of Violation: The city shall provide written notification of any
violation of this chapter to the owner of the vehicle or equipment on which the
violation exists and the consumer, if different, shall demand that the
corrective action be taken within twenty four (24) hours of the delivery of
such notification. The city, at the request of the owner or consumer, may
authorize an extension of time for the completion or any modification of the
required corrective action upon good cause shown. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-8: SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Authority Of City: If the owner or consumer fails to take the required
corrective action within twenty four (24) hours of the delivery of a notice of
violation of this chapter, the city, in its own discretion, may suspend any
business license issued to the owner and/or consumer.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Reinstatement Of Business License: No business license suspended under
this section may be reinstated until all outstanding fines and fees are paid,
and all violations or defects are corrected and the city has inspected and
approved the corrections. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012; amd. 2014 Code)
3-4-9: RESTITUTION:
If contamination of the city water system occurs by means of a violation of
this chapter, the owner of the property or equipment in violation and/or the
party responsible for such contamination, must bear the cost of cleanup of the
city water system. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012)
3-4-10: PENALTY:
A violation of this chapter shall be a class B misdemeanor and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each violation of this chapter shall be considered to be a
separate offense. (Ord. 2012.02, 3-8-2012; amd. 2014 Code)

3-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:

Clerk. This Chapter shall not apply to the following or any other event

a quorum is present:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A funeral procession;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Students going to and from school classes. Also school-sponsored

3-5-3: APPLICATION FOR SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE; FEE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Filing Period: An application for a Special Event License shall be

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Information Required: The application for the Special Event License

Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The name, mailing address and telephone number of the person or

Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If the Special Event is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of

Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the

Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â If the Special Event is a race or parade:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The route to be traveled, including the starting point and the

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A statement as to whether the Special Event will occupy all or
only a portion of the width of any street proposed to be traversed; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â The location by street or any other location of any assembly
areas for such Special Event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â If the Special Event is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or
for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for the Special Event

on his/her/its behalf;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The person signing the Special Event License shall be responsible
for reading and knowing the contents of, and agreeing to follow the

Code, the Utah Code and the Utah State Tax Code; and shall provide evidence of

Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Special Events that include food items will provide a list of
exhibitors or vendors along with evidence of compliance with State and County
laws and ordinances regulated by the Washington County Health Department and
International Fire Code;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â A plan addressing the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Access: Specific areas shall be designated for ingress and egress
of emergency vehicles, including appropriate barriers to regulate vehicular and
pedestrian traffic.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Control Plan: A plan establishing adequate provisions for traffic
control, crowd control, patron control, and enforcement of city ordinances,
state and federal laws and any other applicable regulations, including, but not

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Emergency Services: First aid supplies and equipment, and

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Parking: Temporary off-street parking shall be provided at the
rate of one vehicle for every four (4) persons reasonably expected to attend

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Sanitation Facilities: Adequate sanitation facilities shall be
provided based on the duration of the Special Event and on the number of
persons reasonably expected to participate.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Security: A plan shall be approved establishing the number and
type of law enforcement and security personnel that will be present at the
Special Event to monitor and facilitate the use and provide spectator or

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â Existing Zoning: A designation of existing zoning of the site and
contiguous properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â Description Of Other Uses: Written description of other uses and/
or structures on the property and on contiguous properties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â i.Â Â Â Site Plan: Site plan, drawn to scale, showing proposed locations
and uses of all temporary structures.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Late Applications: The City Clerk, where good cause is shown therefor,
shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed
less than thirty (30) days before the date such Special Event is proposed to be
conducted. A late fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be imposed for a late
application.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â License Fee: There shall be paid at the time of filing the application
for a Special Event License a fee in the amount designated by the City Council
from time to time and set forth in the City's Uniform Fee Schedule. (Ord.
2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-4: DEPOSIT AND INSURANCE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â If it is reasonably expected that the Special Event will result in the
necessity of street cleaning, has the potential for unusual noise, or other
disruption of commercial activity in the City, or will otherwise pose a hazard
to public health and safety of the City, the City may require the applicant to
post a deposit (as determined by the City Clerk) to assure compliance with the
standards and conditions required in the Special Event License.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All applicants may be required, if deemed necessary, for public health
and safety to provide the City with a valid certificate of liability insurance
written through carriers acceptable to the City and Utah Local Governments
Trust. Said liability insurance shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Provide bodily injury and property damage liability protection in
the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence or such
additional amount as may be determined from time to time by City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The applicant must be specified as the insured. The certificate
shall name Toquerville City, its officers and agents, as an "additional
insured" and must specify that the applicant's insurance shall be primary to
any insurance carried by the City.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A certificate of insurance shall be properly executed with the
original signature of the authorizing insurance agent. A copy of the insurance
certificate is required prior to the Special Event License being issued and
shall not be canceled prior to giving the City at least ten (10) days' written
notice of such cancellation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â If alcohol is to be consumed, liquor liability coverage is also
required. Special Events open to the general public or private events that
charge for alcohol served must adhere to Utah State Division of Alcoholic
Beverage Control ("DABC") and provide a copy of the single event permit issued
by DABC prior to the Special Event.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â In every case the Special Event location shall be restored to its
condition prior to the event. This is to include, but not be limited to,
cleaning of streets, sidewalks and gutters, repair damaged streets, sidewalks,
utilities, street signs, etc. If the City is required to correct problems or
clean up after a Special Event, the responsible party will be billed for the
cost of correction and/or cleanup if the Deposit made per subsection A of this
section is not sufficient to cover the cost of correction and/or cleanup. If no
correction and/or cleanup is required, the deposit made per subsection A of
this section will be refunded within thirty (30) days after the Special Event.
(Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)

and input on the application:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Washington County Sheriff's Department (or applicable law enforcement

3-5-6: STANDARDS FOR ISSUANCE:
The City Clerk shall issue a Special Event License as provided for hereunder
when, from consideration of the application and from such other information as
may otherwise be obtained, he or she finds that:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Conducting the proposed Special Event will not substantially interrupt
the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Conducting the proposed Special Event will not require the diversion of
so great a number of law enforcement or city personnel to properly police the
event as to prevent normal police protection and provision of City services to
the residents of City;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Conducting the proposed Special Event will not require the diversion of
so great a number of emergency response service personnel from the Hurricane
Valley Fire District so as to prevent normal emergency response service to
other portions of the City;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The concentration of persons, animals and/or vehicles at any assembly
points of the proposed Special Event will not unduly interfere with proper fire
and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such
event areas;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Conducting the proposed Special Event is not reasonably likely to cause
injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a
disturbance;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The proposed Special Event is scheduled in such a manner as to not
conflict with other events or things which may require law enforcement, fire,
ambulance, or other personnel at the same time as the event;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â The proposed Special Event is not to be held for the sole purpose of
advertising any product, goods or commercial activity;
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â If the sole purpose of the Special Event is to advertise any product,
goods or commercial activity or for private profit, the person or party
responsible will be required to pay for all costs and/or services. (Ord.
2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-7: NOTICE OF REJECTION:
The City Clerk shall act upon the application for a Special Event License
within ten (10) business days after the filing thereof. If the City Clerk
disapproves the application, notice shall be mailed to the applicant within ten
(10) business days after the date upon which the application was filed, stating
the reasons for denial of the application. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-8: MODIFIED SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE:
The City Clerk, in denying an application for a Special Event License, shall be
empowered to authorize to issue a modified Special Event License allowing the
applicant to conduct the Special Event on a date, at a time, at a location or
over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring
to accept the modified Special Event License shall, within ten (10) business
days after notice of the action of the City Clerk, file a written notice of
acceptance with the City Clerk. A modified Special Event License shall conform
to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a normal Special Event
License issued under this Chapter. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-9: CONTENTS OF SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Each Special Event License shall state the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Special Event sponsor and applicant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Special Event date or dates and times of operation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Special Event location;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The number and location of any City personnel required and the rate
of pay applicable;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The portions of any street to be traversed that may be occupied by
the Special Event;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The list of any other tax, Utah Department of Transportation
("UDOT"), or other permits required in addition to the City issued Special
Event License to be provided to the City prior to the Special Event; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Such other information and conditions as the City Clerk shall find
necessary and desirable for the enforcement of this Chapter and the Toquerville
Code;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A completed application must be approved and Special Event License
issued at least thirty (30) days prior to the Special Event. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-
20-2021)
3-5-10: RULES, REGULATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Duties Of Event Organizer: The Special Event Organizer shall ensure
compliance with all Special Event License directions and conditions and with
all applicable laws and ordinances.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Public Conduct During Special Event:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Interference: No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede
or interfere with any event or event assembly, or with any person, vehicle or
animal participating or used in a Special Event.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Driving Through Events: No driver of a vehicle shall drive between
the vehicles or persons comprising an event when such vehicles or persons are
in motion and are conspicuously designated as an event, unless specifically
directed to do so by a law enforcement officer.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Parking On Parade Or Race Route: The City Zoning Administrator and
law enforcement officials shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary,
to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a public street or part
thereof constituting a part of the route of a Special Event. The City or
Special Event Organizer may post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful
for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof.
However, no person shall be liable for parking on the street that is not posted
in a manner provided herein, or who is not otherwise advised not to park
thereon by a law enforcement officer or City personnel working the Special
Event. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-11: APPEAL PROCEDURE:
Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a Special
Event License to the City Council. The appeal shall be submitted within ten
(10) days after notice of denial. The City Council shall act upon the appeal
within ten (10) days after its receipt. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-12: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The City Clerk shall have the authority to revoke a Special Event license
issued hereunder upon failure of the applicant or participants in the Special
Event to meet the standards and conditions provided herein and on the Special
Event License. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
3-5-13: PENALTY:
Violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be a class B
misdemeanor, subject to penalty as provided in Section
1-4-1 of the Toquerville Code, or such lesser offense as the City Attorney in
his/her discretion shall choose. (Ord. 2021.01, 1-20-2021)
CHAPTER 6
HOME OCCUPATIONS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Title And Purpose

3-6-1: TITLE AND PURPOSE:
This chapter shall be known and cited as the TOQUERVILLE HOME OCCUPATION
ORDINANCE. The purpose and intent of this chapter is to allow persons, in
compliance with the requirements of this chapter to utilize a portion of their
residential premises as a place of business. Such business shall only be
operated by residents in the home and shall not be of such nature or scope that
the operation of the business disrupts neighbors or detracts, changes or
modifies the character of the neighborhood in which it is located. (Ord.
2023.05, 5-17-2023; amd. Ord. 2023.15, 6-21-2023)
3-6-2: APPLICABILITY:
The requirements of this chapter shall apply to all home occupations within the
following zoning areas inside the City:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Single-Family Residential (R-1-12, R-1-15 and R-1-20);
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Multiple Use District (MU-20);
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Agricultural District (A);
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Multiple-Family District (RM-1 and RM-2). (Ord. 2023.05, 5-17-2023;
amd. Ord. 2023.15, 6-21-2023)
3-6-3: DEFINITIONS:
All other definitions set forth in this title not specifically modified by this
section are incorporated herein by this reference. The following words and
phrases used in this chapter shall have the following meanings, unless a
different meaning clearly appears from the context:
Â

3-6-4: LICENSES REQUIRED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Home Occupation License: To assure compliance -with the provisions of
this title and to better protect the character of affected neighborhoods in the
City, a home occupation license must be approved by City Development staff
before a structure on the residential premises may be used for a home
occupation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Business License: In addition to obtaining a home occupation permit,
any person wishing to conduct a home occupation upon residential premises must
also obtain and maintain a valid business license from the City, provided
however that the City shall not charge any license fee for the business
license.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â State Sales Tax License: If required by the State, a State Sales Tax
license shall be issued to the home occupation, with the City listed as a
business location. (Ord. 2023.05, 5-17-2023)
3-6-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for a home occupation permit license shall contain the
following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The name, contact information, and home address of the person applying
for the permit;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The registered name of the business, if applicable;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The Federal tax identification (EIN) number of the business entity, if
applicable;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â A brief description of the type of business/home occupation to be
engaged in;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â A State tax identification number, if applicable;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â A licensure number issued by the State Department of Professional and
Occupational Licensing, if applicable;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Proof that the home occupation is State licensed or exempt, if
